problem.para: Suppose V is a subvector space of \RNr[n] with \dim(V)=20, and let S be a subset of \RNr[n]. How many vectors can there be in S if

answer.para: S contains at least 20 vectors, possibly infinitely many.

solution.para: It is possible to select from S a basis for V, and this basis must have exactly 20 vectors.

problem.para: \span(S) contains V

answer.para: S contains at least 20 vectors, possibly infinitely many.

solution.para: It is possible to select from S a basis for \span(S), and \span(S) has dimension at least 20 as it contains V. Therefore S must have at least \dim(\span(S)) \geq 20 vectors.

problem.para: V contains \span(S).

answer.para: S can have any number of vectors.

solution.para: All we know is that \span(S) is contained in V. But this relationship does not impose any constraint on the number of vectors in S.

problem.para: S is linearly independent and V contains S.

answer.para: S can have at most 20 vectors.

solution.para: S can be completed to a basis of V. Such a basis has exactly 20 vectors. Therefore S can have at most 20 vectors.

solution.para: An arbitrary vector space V need not have anything like ‘standard coordinates‘. Even if V has some set of standard coordinates, changing from \EuScript{B}-coordinates to standard coordinates does not change the vector in V to a vector in \RNr[3] (unless, of course, V=\RNr[3] in which case \Vect{x} has been in \RNr[3] all along).
